SafetyInspectionBy: Fire Code Inpsection by local CEO.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Commodore Plastics, LLC is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. The facility has on-site support to coordinate health, safety and environmental programs.



The facility maintains a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers design, installation, operation, maintenance and training for affected processes.  In the event that any unforeseeable release might still occur, the facility coordinates emergency response primarily with local fire departments.  



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance(s)



The facility manufactures various foam products.  The foam manufacturing process uses regulated flammable gas as a blowing agent.  The maximum inventory of blowing agent at the facility exceeds the 10,000-lb RMP threshold.



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Summarized below is a brief description of the facility?s program elements:



Process Safety Information

The facility maintains process safety information that describes chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the covered process.



Process Hazard Analysis

In order to identify and then control the hazards of the process, the facility has performed a What-If/Checklist analysis using a team of qualified personnel and led by a qualified outside consultant.  The hazard review is updated at least every 5 years or when major changes are made.  The findings are addressed in a timely manner and documented.



Operating Procedures

To ensure the covered process is operated safely, written operating instructions have been developed, maintained and made available to operators.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as start-up, shutdown, normal operation, temporary operations, emergency shutdown and emergency operation.



Training

The facility trains employees that operate covered processes initially, as c

hanges are made and conducts refresher training



Mechanical Integrity

The facility?s maintenance personnel perform documented maintenance on covered process equipment to ensure proper operation.  The work is performed by trained maintenance personnel and the equipment includes storage tanks, piping systems, relief vent and vent systems, control pumps, etc.



Management of Change

Written Management of Change procedures are maintained at the facility, which cover changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Operating and maintenance personnel affected by changes are made aware of the changes and trained as needed.



Pre-Start Up Safety Reviews

These reviews are conducted for initial startups and following modifications.  The reviews confirm that construction, equipment and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for a safe startup prior to placing the equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

Audits will be conducted to ensure that the provisions of PSM and RMP are being implemented.  Any necessary corrective actions are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation

Facility personnel promptly investigate any incident that has or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  The investigations seek to identify root causes and any corrective actions necessary to prevent recurrences.



Contractors

The facility occasionally uses outside contractors to perform specialized maintenance or construction activities.  Hazards that could be encountered related to the covered process are reviewed as well as site-specific safety rules and emergency response procedures.





The affected process at the facility is equipped with various process controls and mitigation systems such as relief valves, check valves, automatic shutoffs, alarms, etc. and maintains operating procedures to decrease the potential for a release event. 







Five-Year Accident History



There have bee

n no significant accidental releases from the covered process during the past 5 years.



Emergency Response Plan



The facility maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with potential accidents related the covered process.  The plan includes first aid response, notification of emergency responders and evacuation. Commodore employees do not directly respond to incidents such as fires beyond the incipient stage.  The plan is communicated to employees and updated as needed. The facility EH&S Manager is active member of local LEPC.



Planned Stages to Improve Safety



Commodore involves its employees in managing safety by setting goals, conducting safety meetings/training, forming safety teams and enforcing safety rules.
